The reason you see the background color outside the rounded corners of your border is that the `background` modifier is applied before (under) the shape of the border, so the background fills the entire rectangle, ignoring the border's curvature.

To fix this, you need to apply the rounded shape to both the background and border. The order of the background and border (and their shape argument) is important. Here is the correct way:

```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier
 .padding(top = 25.dp)
 .border(1.dp, Color.Black, RoundedCornerShape(16.dp))
 .background(MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary, RoundedCornerShape(16.dp))
) {
 // ... Text ...
}
```

- The `border` comes first, then the `background`, and both use `RoundedCornerShape(16.dp)`.

Alternatively, you can use `clip` before background if you want to strictly clip children inside the shape (especially important if you're using things like images):

```kotlin
Box(
 modifier = Modifier
 .padding(top = 25.dp)
 .border(1.dp, Color.Black, RoundedCornerShape(16.dp))
 .clip(RoundedCornerShape(16.dp))
 .background(MaterialTheme.colorScheme.primary)
) {
 // ... Text ...
}
```

This will ensure that your background color and border match the rounded corners and you do not see the background color extending beyond the border.

```kotlin
 .padding(top = 10.dp)
 .border(1.dp, color = Color.Black, RoundedCornerShape(16.dp))

 indication = rememberRipple(bounded = true)
 )
) {

 "Text use as a card",
 modifier = Modifier.padding(10.dp),
 color = Color.White,
 textAlign = TextAlign.Center,
 )
}
```

### 2. Using Surface (Material3 recommended way)

`Surface` automatically applies ripple effect and Material styling on click:

```kotlin
import androidx.compose.material3.Surface

Surface(
 shape = RoundedCornerShape(16.dp),
 color = MaterialTheme.colorScheme.secondary,
 border = BorderStroke(1.dp, Color.Black),
 modifier = Modifier.padding(top = 10.dp),
 onClick = { /* Your click action */ }, // Surface is clickable by default when onClick is provided!
) {
 Text(
 "Text use as a card",
 modifier = Modifier.padding(10.dp),
 color = Color.White,
 textAlign = TextAlign.Center,
 )
}
```

#### Notes:

- Surface is the preferred way for Material design, but using `Box`+`clickable` is also common when you want more control.
